children.subject: Adding on, 126 has roughly the same workload/difficulty as 170. YMMV but many also say that 126 is the hardest eecs course at Cal.

I took 126 and 170 in the same semester and I spent more time on 170 Homeworks than 126 Homeworks but I did feel the material in 170 was more straightforward in a sense. 

It's always hard to answer questions like : "is this class harder than this one". It really depends on you. Some people that have better intuition on combinatorial/discrete style problems would probably find 170 easier than 126, which has a more calculus style class feel to it (if that makes sense). Overall, both classes require a good amount of effort if you really want to get a lot out of them.

CS 188 and CS 61C are both very work-heavy classes in my experience. While the material being covered might not be dense, these courses guarantee that there should exist no point in time throughout the semester when you don't have a homework/lab/project to work on. I have not taken 126 so I can't say anything about that, but with 188 and 61C you already have a rather busy semester. I would suggest taking 110 or 113 only if you already most of the material that will be covered in at least one of the four courses you end up taking, otherwise you may not have enough time to actually learn any of the material.

Workload questions are always weird cause it totally depends on you. That being said, 4 techs is always a lot - and 61c/126 are both known to be relatively high amounts of work compared to other techs.

What have you taken in the past/how difficult has it been for you?

Even if you work your hard ass off, it will still be very unlikely to handle all of them, if your objective is to get an A for all of them. 126 will be very very hard, but I think it also depends on people, I would say a good indicator will be if you can solve CS 70 harder Probability questions in a very intuitive sense. (I'm not talking about very easy placing ball questions or straightforward Bayes' Theorem questions) The difficulty in questions will spike up immediately after you go to the class, the problem sets are incredibly hard to solve though the concepts seem not so advanced. Also due to the relative smaller size of this class, you will be competing with a bunch of most brilliant kids from EECS department and TAs from your lower-div classes, and some of them even struggle with keeping up the concepts. 

So good luck, 126 will possibly be one of the hardest classes you will be taking at Berkeley.

history.content: I am currently enrolled in 126, 188 and 61c. I was wondering if adding Math 110, or possibly Math 113 would be doable in terms of workload.
history.subject: Questions about Sophomore Schedule
